subject: GREAT INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY
content:
GREAT INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY
 
 
 
Science for Georgia is looking for 1-3 interns for the Fall 2024 semester.
Students will gain in-depth understanding of the Science for Georgia Data Analytics Program by contributing to a specific data-for-good story.  The data analysis program is centered on using existing environmental and social data to produce contextualized data stories about the physical, economic and environmental health of Georgia communities. 
 
Gain hands-on experience in storytelling with data, utilizing real world “messy” data, and being part of a project and data management process. 
 
The goal is for the intern to become a “Project Manager” of a data team during a Spring QTM Capstone project class. The product of the QTM Capstone will be a contextualized public-facing data story.
	•	Weekly Hours: 10-20
 
	•	Location: 100% remote. Sci4Ga has co-working space in Atlanta and interns are welcome to join us there.
 
	•	Expected Skills:
	◦	Ability to work in Excel, Python and/or R
	◦	Basic data analysis techniques
	◦	Ability to manage time in a fast-paced environment
	◦	Ability to independently carry out research tasks
	◦	Some previous experience working with geospatial data and GIS software like ArcGIS or GeoPandas or a strong willingness to learn!
 
A full description of the role and expectations can be seen at bit.ly/3AL5lGC
This internship will be for class credit and follow the fall semester calendar.  Students who are selected for this internship will be enrolled in QTM 496R for 3 credit hours.
 
Interested students can complete the application at https://forms.office.com/r/FZe9VrU3BT.
We will begin reviewing applications at 5:00 PM on September 5th.
 
Please email Dr. Kevin McAlister (kevin.mcalister@emory.edu) with any questions.
 
BEST,
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

Date and time :  Thursdays at 5pm-7pm

Credit hours: 2 
 
Course title: Ethical Emerging TechnologiesDescription: This course explores the ethical implications and governance challenges of emerging technologies such as AI, autonomous vehicles, autonomous weapons, digital medicine, blockchain, sustainability and the environment, and IoT. Students will explore key pillars of ethical tech development, including explainability, fairness, bias and privacy, while also learning about the economic impact of emerging technologies such as AI.
Students will develop skills to understand how these technologies impact society and how to approach them responsibly through case studies, discussions, and interactive workshops.
 
This fall join visiting instructor from Google/YouTube, Savneet Singh in QTM's newest seminar course offering.

subject: New Class Announcement
content:
NEW CLASS ANNOUNCEMENT
 
Topics in Quantitative Science: Unlocking the Future with AI
Includes topics related to statistical computing.
 
QTM 285  - Section 2,  Class # 6295
Credit Hours: 3
 
Schedule and Location:   W 4pm-7pm in ONLINE
Instruction Method: Distance Learning
 
Instructor:  Dr. Richard Pocklington 
 
Prompting and Meta Prompting: Unlocking the Future with AI -
Dive into the rapidly evolving field of AI to learn how to use the transformative techniques of prompting and meta prompting in large language models (LLMs). Gain a solid foundation in AI and LLMs fundamentals to broaden your ability to craft effective prompts to elicit desired outputs. Through hands-on projects and case studies, learn to design, optimize, and evaluate prompts for various applications (such as structured text generation and sentiment analysis). Explore advanced topics like Chain of Thought, Graph of Thought, and Tree of Thought to leverage LLMs for complex tasks. Ethical implications of LLMs will also be explored. Engage with cutting-edge research, industry experts, and real-world datasets while developing practical skills in AI frameworks and tools. By course end, be equipped to apply prompting and meta prompting across domains, making significant contributions to your chosen application area with state-of-the-art LLM applications.
To successfully complete this course, students should have completed QTM 100 Intro to Stat Inference and QTM 150 Introduction to Statistical Computing I, or equivalent coursework.
 
Best, 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

(she/her/hers)

subject: New Class Announcement for fall 2024
content:
NEW CLASS ANNOUNCEMENT FOR FALL 2024
 
Intensive version of QTM 220 Regression Analysis and will count for QTM 220 requirement
It is particularly useful for AMS majors and other students with a strong math background
 
 
QTM 285-1 Prediction, Inference, & Causality 
A Rigorous Introduction to Prediction, Inference, and Causality
 
MW 4pm-5:15pm  room 230 - New Psyc Bldg (36 Eagle Row)
F 2:30pm-3:20pm  room 220 - New Psyc Bldg (36 Eagle Row)
 
Instructor:  Dr. David Hirshberg
 
This class will be accepted in place of QTM 220 and there is substantial overlap in content between the two. However, there will be a greater emphasis on the precision with which we move from stories and intuition to formal mathematical reasoning--and back--in this course. Data visualization, including sketching by hand and plotting in R, will be emphasized as a tool for making this connection.
 
A modern, mathematically rigorous introduction to statistical modeling and data-driven decision-making that provides a foundation for upper-level classes in the department. We will focus on prediction---using data we have to tell us something about data we don't, statistical inference---characterizing the uncertainty we have about the accuracy of these predictions, and causal inference---understanding what the relationships we see in the data tell us about the impact of actions we might take. While the class will emphasize the intuitive and mathematical foundations of these concepts, we will also cover the implementation of these techniques in applications using the statistical programming language R.
 
To succeed in this course, students should have the same prerequisites as for QTM 220: (QTM 110 or QTM_OX 110) & (QTM 150 or QTM_OX 150) & (QTM 120 or MATH 210 or MATH_OX 210 or MATH_211 or MATH_OX 211) & [QTM 210 or QTM_OX 210 or ECON 220 or ECON_OX 220 or (MATH 361 and MATH 362)] & (MATH 221 or MATH_OX 221) or equivalent.
 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

subject: SUMMER ANNOUNCEMENT
content:
SUMMER ANNOUNCEMENT
 
 
Invitation to the 2nd AI Summer School, Symposium and Datathon
 
Join us for the 2nd Medical Imaging, AI, and Bias Data Symposium happening from August 19 to August 25, 2024, at Emory University. The focus of this symposium is to collaboratively uncover bias, establish collaborations, and provide the opportunity to work with real data, supported by a team that understands the data. Following the success of last year’s event (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nzXoOyKlOtg), we have observed the need to bridge the communication gap between medical professionals and computer scientists. Therefore, we are dedicating four days to summarizing the common mistakes and pitfalls we have observed, using a case-based approach to learning medical imaging. 
   
During these four days, we will offer a case-based learning curriculum that spans from ICU data to Chest X-ray, as well as breast imaging data. We will also be launching EMBED2, a multi-modal breast imaging data, including 3D imaging (tomosynthesis) and MRI imaging, with improved patient outcomes.  
  
We hope you can join us. Please register here - https://www.datathon.org
 

Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT - 2 JOB OPPORTUNITIES 
 
Research Assistant 
Opportunities available to advanced undergraduate or graduate students. Please see details below and apply via Handshake at the links included in the descriptions.
 
Questions can be directed to McKenzie Beverage or Jo Guldi. 
 
Seeking Data Science Research Assistant to help with project “Text Mining the Documentation of Climate Change.” 
Apply at: https://emory.joinhandshake.com/emp/jobs/8999657 
Applicants should be a mature, independent, and self-directed, capable of asking many questions about what constitutes an ideal set of results, reporting to three faculty from QTM, Law, and Public Health. Student will be required to respond with weekly iterations to the project, booking time with faculty leads, reporting on progress and flagging issues on the way to a final project. 
 
Required skills: textual analysis using R or Python, basic knowledge of tokenization, collocation analysis, topic modeling, word embeddings.  
 
Ideal skillset: a graduate of QTM 340, Text as Data, with some skills web scraping and scraping pdf’s using Selenium. Ideally student has a background in studies in the humanities and/or social sciences, has taken classes on the interpretation of texts and the analysis of historical events, a commitment to climate change and/or social justice. 
 
Pay/Timing: $15/hr. 
Work conditions and project length: Student can be remote or on premises. Commitment is 10-30 hr a week, minimum 10 weeks, up to all summer; continuation into academic year is possible. 
 
To apply please provide a cover letter describing your skills and how they match our requirements, a vita, a link to a LinkedIn or similar URL,  the name and email of one professor who could serve as a reference if contacted.

Must be capable of talking to and developing a plan with another research assistant with a technical background.

subject: NEWS AND ANNOUNCEMENTS - 4-22-2024
content:
For QTM Undergraduates

Monday,
April 22, 2024




 
  
 
 
 

 
 
IMPORTANT  ANNOUNCEMENT 
 
The link for the Data Camp access for Summer 2024 and Fall 2024 is updated.  Access new link below. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

NYC Summer Internship Data Engineering Opportunity: APPLY NOW!
 
Role Summary:  Jain Global is looking for a motivated Data Engineering Intern to help enhance and integrate its existing data processing and retrieval systems into its main data platform. The intern will be instrumental in refining the data architecture to support advanced search functionalities and efficient data handling. The role is for a 2-3 summer month in-person internship in NYC.  See ( attached) job description for details.
 
 
See attached PDF flyer for more details 
 
 
Sandra Ruhlman Smith
 
 
 
 
 
Opportunity
 
Seeking Dataverse Developer
 
Background
 
Recovering the US Hispanic Literary Heritage Program (Recovery) at the University of Houston (UH)  
is the largest Hispanic/Latino humanities research program operating in the United States dedicated 
to researching, locating, preserving and making available all literary-historical documents 
produced by Hispanics/Latinos living in the United States from the Colonial Period to 1980. 
 
Recovery is in the process of creating a customized web-based content repository in Dataverse. 
The repository will hold Recovery’s vast archives and metadata (file formats include JPG, TIFF, PNG, PDF,
CSV, Excel, and Word). 
 
It will allow multi-level access to the assets and their metadata to a range of audiences,
Recovery staff, students, researchers, educators and community members. 
The assets will be made discoverable through fully searchable metadata and indexing on search engines. 
The valuable resource will further scholarship and preservation of Latino historical materials 
(1595 to 1980) through the maintenance, modernization, and consolidation of Recovery archival collections. 
 
To learn more about Recovery, please visit: https://artepublicopress.com/recovery-program/ 
Recovery is seeking a developer who can provide customizations and technical support for this effort. This position will implement Dataverse, install software and begin customizations. Customizations to include, but not limited to, developing APIs to accommodate broader search functionalities, bilingual metadata, metadata linking to image files, auto populate features, batch upload features, expanded user roles, and author ownership. 
This position is expected to meet with the project team and UH IT to discuss the customizations needed, establish a workflow, and acquire university technology clearance.  Additionally, this position will assist in determining the cloud storage service that best suits the project’s needs. 
This position will be remote contract work for 2 years.
Required Qualifications
B.S. Computer Science/Computer Engineering or relevant experience in software development and modification
At least 18 months of programming experience 
The ideal candidate for this position should possess the following:
·         Experience working with Humanities data in a university setting
 
·         Experience working with multilingual datasets and user experience
 
·         Ability to communicate technical information to technical and non-technical personnel at various levels in the organization
 
·         Familiarity with research data management systems, databases, and data handling protocols.
 
·         Experience developing custom software solutions for digital asset management systems (DAMS)
 
·         Experience working with Dataverse or similar platforms
 
·         Experience working with cloud storage services such as AWS and Azure
 
·         Experience installing, running apps/services in Linux
 
·         Knowledge of JavaScript, Payara, PostgreSQL, Solr, and jq
 
·         Knowledge of JSON
 
·         Knowledge of APIs
 
Salary: Salary commensurate with education/experience. This is not a benefits eligible position.
Please send the following as PDFs to apprec@central.uh.edu: Cover Letter, Resume, and names and contact information for 2 professional references
We would like to have this position filled by April 30, 2024.

MESSAGE FROM THE CITY OF ATLANTA TEAM PER THEIR VISIT TO CAMPUS TODAY
 
 
Hey Emory, 
 
Atlanta’s Department of City Planning wants your big ideas for Atlanta’s future growth.
The Atlanta Regional Commission expects Atlanta’s 2050 population to be nearly 700,000 people. That is over 170,000 more residents needing at least 100,000 new housing units.
Where should all these new Atlantans live? What broad development goals should the City adopt? What else comes to mind?
City planners are updating the City’s comprehensive plan with residents, and they are asking these questions. 
 
Student voices are important, so take the City’s surveys and chat with Atlanta city planners who will be at the Quad on Thursday, April 18, 11AM to 1PM.

SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
Applications are open for QTM Ambassadors for 2024-25
Apply here
2024-25 QTM Ambassadors  Application 
 
 
What is a QTM Ambassador?
 
QTM Ambassadors are an important extension of the QTM department.   They serve as representatives of QTM with its programming and external partners/advisory board and have the opportunity to develop skills that will serve them in future professional capacities. This includes hosting  events, conducting interviews, communicating with professionals, and engaging the community and student body.   The Ambassador cohort will consist of 15-20  currently enrolled Sophomores, Juniors and Seniors who have the following:
 
	•	Must be a QTM major or minor
	•	Have completed at least 3 QTM courses
	•	Have a 3.0 GPA
	•	Have good interpersonal skills
	•	Able to meet on Mondays or Fridays at 4:00 PM bi-weekly
	•	Engage in 1-2 hours/week of support & Activity
	•	Participate for the full academic year
 
What are some of the opportunities and benefits?
	•	Participate in QTM Departmental events like QTM Open House, Faculty & Staff Holiday Party,  DataFest and DataBlitz
	•	Serve as the face of the QTM Department at various events 
	•	Assist with QTM Prep programs
	•	Provide insight and feedback to external advisors, faculty and staff
	•	Conduct panel discussions about the QTM programs and QTM Alumni careers
	•	Develop presentation skills and strengthen interpersonal relationship skills
	•	Have an opportunity to network with external partners, advisory board members and QTM Alumni
	•	Being a part of this group and the experience looks great on your resume/portfolio
	•	Various projects will give you the opportunity to exercise what you have already learned
 
Application as due by April 6th 2024
 
If you are interested in joining this group, please fill out the application below.  We would love for you to be a part of this team.

https://quantitative.emory.edu/qtm-opportunities/qtm-ambassadors.html
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Emory Undergraduate Medical Review (EUMR)
We are hosting our annual Emotive Arts Series event this Thursday, April 4th, from 6-8 pm in the Campus Life Pavilion. The Emotive Arts Series seeks to synthesize the arts and medicine, and the topic of this year's Emotive Arts series is Nature vs. Nurture, inspired by the theme of our journal this semester for our 10th anniversary: epigenetics.  The event will include a panel featuring various Emory faculty, dance performances, and the presentation of student art and poetry.
We have extended our submission deadline to April 3rd at 11:59PM to allow more students the opportunity to showcase their talents!

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Professional Women in STEM Panel
 
This Thursday, April 4th,  5:30-7:30 in Candler Library room 123 the Association of Women in Science is holding a Professional Women in STEM Panel. Come listen to professional women tell their personal experiences, explain how they navigated their careers, and give advice in the STEM field. This event gives you the unique opportunity to ask questions and chat with esteemed professional women in the STEM field! 
 
See flyer attached for details
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
China and Climate Change Townhall
 
Carter Center's China Focus Program will be hosting a China and Climate Change Townhall on Emory's campus this Friday. One of our speakers, Angel Hsu, is a professor of Public Policy and is coming to speak on how she utilizes data science to conduct her research. There will be free food and snacks which are all included in the poster I have attached. Please let me know if this is possible and, if so, if there is any other information I could provide. 
 
See flyer attached for details
 
 
 
MESSAGE FROM Gabrielle Gershon
 
My name is Gabby, and I am a medical student currently working on a research project focused on coronary artery calcium phenotypes and their implications for cardiac risk assessment. We are seeking an undergraduate student with skills in data analytics to join our team and help analyze trends in our patient database. 😊
 
The project aims to evaluate coronary artery calcium phenotypes in a diverse patient population, with the ultimate goal of creating a fair and unbiased method for assessing the risk of adverse cardiac events such as strokes and heart attacks based on coronary artery calcium levels. As a member of our team, you will have the opportunity to work with real-world patient data and contribute to groundbreaking research in the field of cardiology.
 
This position offers the opportunity to earn research for credit, providing valuable experience and enhancing your resume. If you are interested in joining our team, please send your resume to me at gabrielle.gershon@emory.edu
 
Thank you for considering this opportunity. I look forward to potentially working together and discussing the project in more detail.

Many of you may be wondering where is the permission code form  that the department normally sends out prior to registration.  Well, this process has been adjusted and most of the courses offered in Fall 2024 will not need a permission code prior to registering.  In other words, if you have the prerequisite(s) required for that course, you should be able to register for it.   Many of the courses prerequisites have been changed (see below) and the OPUS  has been updated to reflect it.  Therefore,  please read the course description in Atlas.  It will tell you which prerequisites you would need to take that course. MESSAGE FROM MADELINE PROCTOR 
 
A student-run publication focused on topics at the forefront of science and medicine. We are holding the 2024 Emotive Arts Series, an annual event hosted by EUMR that synthesizes medicine and the arts, and are calling all poets, writers, and artists to consider contributing their work to be showcased at our event! The theme of this spring's journal, in honor of our 10th year anniversary, is epigenetics, and this event will similarly evaluate the effect of nature and nurture on one's health. The event will feature artists, poets, performers, and a panel with experts from throughout Emory. The event will take place on Thursday, April 4th from 6-8 pm in the Campus Life Pavilion and all submissions will be due by March 31. We were hoping you can share this Google Form with your department listserv to spread the word. In it there is information about the submission deadline and how we plan to collaborate with those interested to show off their work.

The New England Statistical Society (NESS - https://nestat.org) is happy to share the NESS NextGen scholarships for underrepresented minorities in statistics and data science. The purpose of these scholarships is to advance the representation of underrepresented groups in statistics and data science by supporting graduating high school seniors and first/second-year undergraduate students who are interested in pursuing a career in statistics and/or data science. 
 
Eligibility: 
·                     Graduating high school senior or first/second-year undergraduate student 
·                     Black, Indigenous or Person of Color (BIPOC) 
·                     Will be enrolled in a U.S. college or university for the upcoming 2024-2025 academic year. 
·                     Shows a genuine interest in statistics and data science through coursework, extracurricular activities, and/or future goals 
A priority will be given for students who are eligible for a Federal Pell Grant Program (for more information, please see this information page from the U.S. Department of Education). 
Deadline: April 15, 2024 
Amount: at least $1,000 
Applications are currently open, apply here: https://nextgenscholarship.nestat.org/ 
 
Submitted by Sandra Ruhlman Smith

subject: REMINDER - Special Announcement
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT 
 
2024 Summer AI XPERIENCE
     (applications are now open)
          See below and attached flyer
 
 
Emory University's Center for AI Learning and QTM department are excited to solicit applications from students for the 2024 Summer AI Xperience. In this program, students will work in teams of 5 to complete one of many different data science consulting projects. Each of these projects will contain a mixture of programming and data analysis tasks that will require developing a strong substantive knowledge surrounding the problem.
 
To be selected, students need to:
	•	Have been enrolled in classes at Emory in the Spring 2024 semester and be enrolled at Emory in the Fall 2024 semester.
	•	Be in residence in Atlanta, GA between July 1 and August 15.
	•	Attend 3 or 4 in-person team meetings per week.
	•	Be able to commit roughly 20 hours per week to the project over the 6 week period.
	•	Have knowledge of common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	•	Have experience programming in R and/or Python:
	◦	Ability to load in and manipulate large data sets
	◦	Ability to clean potentially messy data into workable formats
	◦	Knowledge of common programming control structures 
	◦	Ability to write and debug original functions
	◦	Ability to implement common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	◦	Ability to read documentation about new methods and implement them
 
Review of applications will begin on March 7, 2024.  However, all applications will be considered if submitted prior to 5:00 PM on March 19, 2024.  Prior to final selection, some students may be asked to do a short in-person interview.  All students will be informed of the status of their application no later than March 21, 2024.
 
Students who are admitted to this program will have the option to participate in exchange for credit. For example, QTM majors and minors who participate may choose to count this experience as 3 credit hours of QTM 498R. QTM 498R may count as a 300+ level elective towards your QTM degree (or as an experiential elective for those on the Data Science track).  Note that most QTM majors/minors may only count one semester of QTM 498R or QTM 495A/495BW towards their degree. We will work with your department's leadership to confirm what course codes are applicable for your experience.
 
Students who choose to take advantage of any of these options will be required to pay the associated tuition. You can notate if you would like to enroll in 3 or 6 credit hours, which would impact whether financial aid could be applied. Unfortunately, our funding model does not allow us to cover this tuition, so paying this will be your responsibility. The tuition cost and information about need-based financial aid can be found at https://oue.college.emory.edu/advising/summer-school/tuition-financial-aid.html.
 
Students will be asked in this survey whether they are interested in counting this program towards an elective course requirement, as opposed to treating this experience as an internship without credit. content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT 
 
2024 Summer AI XPERIENCE
     (applications are now open)
          See below and attached flyer
 
 
Emory University's Center for AI Learning and QTM department are excited to solicit applications from students for the 2024 Summer AI Xperience. In this program, students will work in teams of 5 to complete one of many different data science consulting projects. Each of these projects will contain a mixture of programming and data analysis tasks that will require developing a strong substantive knowledge surrounding the problem.
 
To be selected, students need to:
	•	Have been enrolled in classes at Emory in the Spring 2024 semester and be enrolled at Emory in the Fall 2024 semester.
	•	Be in residence in Atlanta, GA between July 1 and August 15.
	•	Attend 3 or 4 in-person team meetings per week.
	•	Be able to commit roughly 20 hours per week to the project over the 6 week period.
	•	Have knowledge of common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	•	Have experience programming in R and/or Python:
	◦	Ability to load in and manipulate large data sets
	◦	Ability to clean potentially messy data into workable formats
	◦	Knowledge of common programming control structures 
	◦	Ability to write and debug original functions
	◦	Ability to implement common statistical analysis and machine learning methods
	◦	Ability to read documentation about new methods and implement them
 
Review of applications will begin on March 7, 2024.  However, all applications will be considered if submitted prior to 5:00 PM on March 19, 2024.  Prior to final selection, some students may be asked to do a short in-person interview.  All students will be informed of the status of their application no later than March 21, 2024.

Opportunity
 
STATISTICAL STAFF ANALYST POSITION
 
See attached flyer for details 
 
 
 

 
 
 
Message from
Margaret Corcoran Recruitment  Director  with Green Corps. 
Field School for Environmental Organizing 
 
We are looking for people who are concerned by the state of the environment and who want to do something about it. Our yearlong program has prepared recent college graduates for 30 years to launch a career in environmental  organizing and advocacy by providing hands-on experience running campaigns with groups like the Wilderness Society, Endangered Species Coalition, Mighty Earth and more. We then connect our graduates to jobs in the environmental and social change movement.
 
Green Corps Organizer Program - The Field School for Environmental Organizing
Green Corps is looking for college graduates who are ready to take on the biggest environmental challenges of our day.
Learn more and apply on our website!
 
The planet needs all the help it can get. To win now and build a strong foundation for lasting progress, we need people who know how to organize: to run organizations and campaigns that will inspire the support and action we need to save our environment. Our program starts with intensive classroom training. You learn about issues and campaigns, organizing theory and principles, and skills from recruiting volunteers to staging a media event. Then, you move to a more hands-on experience. You make a difference on important campaigns to transition our country to clean energy, protect wildlife, and more. For example, Lauren Karpinski, an organizer from the Green Corps Class of 2019, brought together a coalition of 40 groups that helped win a landmark solar energy bill in Arkansas.
 
We’re accepting the top 20 candidates for our 2024-2025 program. Graduates will join our more than 400 alumni who are leading environmental campaigns and organizations across the country. If you’re passionate about the environment and ready to learn and practice the craft of organizing after graduation, apply today!
 
Not a graduating senior? Add your name to our list to receive updates about Green Corps including summer internships and jobs in the environmental and broader social change field!
 
Green Corps’ year-long program begins in August 2024 with introductory classroom training, and continues with field placements in multiple locations across the U.S. Candidates must be willing to relocate. Please contact Margaret Corcoran at margaret@greencorps.org with additional questions.
 
Green Corps is part of The Public Interest Network, which operates and supports organizations committed to a shared vision of a better world and a  strategic approach to social change. Visit publicinterestnetwork.org to learn more. Green Corps is an equal opportunity employer. The target annual compensation for this position is $32,500 (but compensation may range between $32,500 and $39,000 depending on location). Green Corps' benefits package includes medical insurance for employees and dependents, needs-based student loan assistance, commuter benefit program, sick pay (60-72 hours/year depending on location), and 80 hours (2 weeks) of accrued vacation. We also offer short-term positions, an excellent training program, and opportunities for advancement.
 
Need more information contact her at (617) 901-6114.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
LUNCH & LEARN
 
The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS) and the Envisioning Baroque Rome digital humanities project invite you for a one-hour round-table Lunch & Learn at noon on Thursday, March 21st in Woodruff Library.
Enjoy a provided lunch while the project team discusses the process of building a 3D model of the city of Rome. Envisioning Baroque Rome began in 2013 with the goal of rebuilding Rome in 1676 according to the map of that year, Nuova piante et alzata della città di Roma, and other prints by artist Giovanni Battista Falda. Led by Sarah McPhee, Samuel Candler Dobbs Professor of Art History, the round-table will include ECDS staff Joanna Mundy, Ian Burr, and John Halbert, and artist Nicole Costello Matthews. The team will discuss the research, modeling, texturing, and animation of Baroque Rome, and you will have an opportunity to explore the newest version of the 3D city yourself!
 
Learn about the recent research in the project and stroll the streets of Rome with Giovanni Battista Falda.
 
We hope that you are able to attend. To RSVP, fill out this form by Monday, March 18th. If you have any questions, please email Joanna Mundy (jcmundy@emory.edu).
 
Submitted by Joanna Mundy

Ringle is a company that provides undergraduate and graduate students with the opportunity to teach English to Korean students. Ringle’s mission is to break down language barriers and allow its members to exchange knowledge and help each other grow.
 
We are seeking talented individuals to join our team and teach English to students around the world! We are looking for tutors with a wide variety of backgrounds and interests from top universities like Emory University.
·         No past teaching experience necessary but native-level fluency in English is required
·         The position is super flexible with NO minimum working hours - You make your own schedule!

·         The position is fully remote through the Ringle interface and Zoom
·         Starting rate is $9.50 for a 20-minute lesson and $17 for a 40-minute lesson with additional bonuses and promotions available

This accelerated, hands-on summer program is offered to student founders with nonprofit or for-profit ventures from ideation through launch stage. The Summer Incubator will run from approximately May 15 to July 30.
The details:
•         The Hatchery will offer financial support up to 40 hours per week at $15/hour per venture for attendance at Accelerator sessions and work done on participant's venture.

subject: SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT FROM DR. KEVIN MCALISTER
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT FROM DR. KEVIN MCALISTER, QTM DIRECTOR OF RESEARCH
 
DataThink is a 10-week data micro-consulting project hosted by the QTM Department and Center for Artificial Intelligence Learning where students will work in teams to solve real problems with real data. Each team will learn the context of the problem and develop a data-driven solution. Participants will gain exposure to the world of professional data analytics, working on projects very similar to those that analysts would in their day-to-day work.
Each team of 5 will be working with data from the Better Business Bureau (BBB) to develop insights to understand how to better communicate with businesses (particularly women and black-owned businesses) that do not currently take advantage of the BBB's local business credibility services. Teams will work together to develop an analysis given the research question to be presented as a poster at the DataThink end of year showcase with the best projects (as judged by a panel of data scientists from around the Atlanta community) receiving a best-in-show award and having the teams' names placed on a plaque.  Students will also prepare a 3-minute lightning talk to describe their work and conclusions that will be presented to the BBB.  The end-of-semester showcase and presentations will be an excellent opportunity to meet with data scientists from around Emory's campus and in the Atlanta community at large.Beginning this semester, all participants in the DataThink program will be expected to attend weekly meetings on Tuesdays from 5:30 - 6:45 in PAIS 290.  The goal of these meetings is to provide students with a common time and place to meet with their teams and discuss how their analysis can progress.  Additionally, each weekly meeting will begin with a 20-minute lecture on an important topic in data science that you may or may not have covered in any of your previous classes.  Topics will include developing meaningful summary tables, string processing, joining multiple data sources using SQL syntax, effectively designing a project poster, etc.To be allowed at the end of semester event, students must attend at least two-thirds of these weekly meetings.  Attendance will be checked via QR code.  As such, it is expected that students applying to participate in this program will have this block of time free in their weekly schedule.  If this time does not work for you, know that the DataThink program will be offered each semester and you are more than welcome to apply in later semesters.  Students with all kinds of experience levels are encouraged to apply. However, selected students will be expected to be able to work with Python in order to perform analysis.  Teams will be created in such a way to induce the greatest experiential diversity within each team as to allow those with less experience to learn from students with more background in programming.   Selected students will gain experience in the following areas:
	•	Data Storytelling
	•	Insight development for a real client
	•	Professional experience to build one’s resume
	•	In-demand data technical skills such as Python, SQL, and data visualization tools
	•	Collaboration and teamwork in the data space
To be considered, please have your application in by 5:00 PM on Wednesday, January 31st.  The application can be found at https://forms.office.com/r/NaVXn8Q0T8.  If the embedded hyperlink does not work, please copy and paste this address into your browser: https://forms.office.com/r/NaVXn8Q0T8
 
The first weekly meeting will take place at 5:30 on February 6th.  
 
If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to Kevin McAlister at kevin.mcalister@emory.edu.
 
 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

GREAT OPPORTUNITY
MARC Undergraduate Scholar 2023-2024 cohort
The Maximizing Student Access to Research Careers (MARC) Undergraduate Scholars Program is a National Institutes of Health (NIH)-funded, two-year research and academic program for undergraduate scholars in STEM research (additional information on the MARC grant can be found here). The program focuses on multi-level mentoring, research integrity, and career preparation and planning to nurture students to become competitive applicants and successful graduates from high-caliber Ph.D. programs in the biomedical and behavioral sciences fields. Moreover, selected MARC Scholars receive up to $16,000 in tuition, a $14,340 stipend during the academic year, a stipend to support summer research,  and a $1000 travel award to attend scientific meetings annually! 
  
To be eligible for funding, undergraduate applicants must  
(1) be a U.S. citizen or permanent resident from a group underrepresented (UR) in science,   a first-generation college student, or from a disadvantaged background, 
(2) be a current second- or third-year student with a preference for second year students who can complete the two-year term of the award, and 
(3) be interested in a Ph.D. granting program in a behavioral or biomedical field (please note this program is not for pre-med students with the exception of students committed to M.D./Ph.D. training). 
  
The deadline for the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application and required Faculty Recommendation Questionnaire, which will be sent directly to the recommender, is Friday, February 2nd, 2024, at 11:59 pm. Students can access the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application via College Connect. After signing onto College Connect with an Emory NetID, students should click on the Application Center to find the MARC Undergraduate Scholar Application under the Undergraduate Research Programs category (see below for a graphic).

The course aims to provide comprehensive insights into this rapidly evolving field.

Opportunity
 
New Independent Study Course/Extracurricular Activity - Simuvaction on AI 2024
Simulation - Innovation - Action (Simuvaction), hosted by the Consulat General de France in Atlanta, the Emory Center for Ethics, and the Georgia Institute of Technology, is a challenging and stimulating program for 40 university students from diverse international and interdisciplinary backgrounds. 
 
Over 6 to 8 weeks, students adopt roles such as heads of state, journalists, and lobbyists, engaging in a simulated environment that mirrors the complexities of global AI policy making. The program culminates in a four-day intensive session in Atlanta (March 16 - March 19), where students apply their learning in a high-stakes negotiation scenario in drafting, debating, and adopting a text as if they were members of the Global Partnership on AI. 
 
Designed to bridge the gap between academic study and real-world policy challenges, Simuvaction is an opportunity for students to not only understand the intricacies of AI ethics but also to raise their voice on a topic which will shape their future. 
 
The deadline for enrollment is December 15, 2023. Scheduled class dates are January 15 - March 20, 2024. Visit the Simuvaction website for more information or email Vrushali.Thakkar@emory.edu or acourri@emory.edu with your resume for enrollment.

OPPORTUNITY 
 
 
PhD Studentship Opportunity
 
4-year PhD studentship at University of Leicester in collaboration with University of Birmingham and AstraZeneca, for candidates with strong statistical background.
 
Title: Model and data-driven solutions for regulatory and HTA decision-making to address emerging challenges in drug development in cancer
Supervisors: Prof Sylwia Bujkiewicz (UoL), Prof Richard Riley (UoB) and Dr Sam Khan (UoL)
Industry partner: Dr Daniel Jackson, AstraZeneca

Collaborator: Dr Janharpreet Singh (UoL)
This project will tackle methodological challenges occurring at different milestones of drug development process, including regulatory approvals and particularly HTA decision-making by agencies such as NICE, when evaluating new cancer therapies. Modern cancer therapies are often targeted to small subsets of patients who harbour a particular biomarker. Survival data from clinical trials evaluating the effectiveness of therapies in a cancer subtype may be limited. You will explore use of other sources of data; based on alternative outcomes, study types or other cancers, which may need to be synthesised efficiently for reliable policy decisions. 
You will apply a range of modern tools from biostatistics (including Bayesian statistics, meta-analysis and survival analysis), epidemiology and data science and develop novel approaches for evaluation of cancer therapies.
This project is part of an exciting collaboration with University of Birmingham and AstraZeneca. You will benefit from an experienced supervisory team with expertise in statistics and oncology and an industry partner. This PhD in Biostatistics will provide you with an opportunity to develop advanced analytical skills, gain insight into drug development and decision-making processes and influence important decisions in healthcare. A suitable candidate will have MSc in Statistics, Medical Statistics or a related discipline.
 
See https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmore.bham.ac.uk%2Fmrc-aim%2Fphd-opportunities%2F&data=05%7C01%7Csylwia.bujkiewicz%40leicester.ac.uk%7C3dc05dbfa44849db697908dbf0bc24b9%7Caebecd6a31d44b0195ce8274afe853d9%7C0%7C0%7C638368463077853590%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=gS7m1yB5qg35tR4HV3muMdfYCe1JhBNjFTy9IPL%2FGSs%3D&reserved=0 for more details.
 
Application deadline Friday 12 January 2024. Open to UK and international students.
 
Webinars for prospective applicants:
·         Monday 11 December at 18:30 GMT 
·         Wednesday 13 December 2023 at 11:00 GMT.
 
https://le.ac.uk/study/research-degrees/funded-opportunities/mrc-aim-dtp
 
Questions? Contact:  Sylwia Bujkiewicz, Professor of Biostatistics University of Leicester, sylwia.bujkiewicz@le.ac.uk
 
 
 
Submitted by Sandra Ruhlman Smith
 
 
 
OPPORTUNITY 
 
 
 

EU MSCA SHARE-CTD Doctoral Network,
ATTN QTM Seniors 
We are excited to announce the call for applications for the EU MSCA SHARE-CTD Doctoral Network, a European Union-funded initiative designed to foster excellence in clinical trial data sharing. This three year program is specially tailored for outstanding students in data science, biostatistics, computer science, medicine, clinical trials, (clinical) epidemiology or related disciplines.
SHARE-CTD is a European doctoral network spanning universities in Berlin, Göttingen, Lyon, Munich, Padova, Rennes, Utrecht, Vienna, and Zurich. The program offers a unique opportunity to engage in cutting-edge research focused on the sharing and re-using of clinical trial data, with an emphasis on Open Science.
The projects encompass topics such as:
Data sharing for validation of prognostic and predictive models in clinical trials. Assessing the impact and methodologies of clinical trial data sharing. Innovations in data anonymization, privacy protection, and automated screening tools. Meta-analyses in mental health and cross-design synthesis in health technology assessment. Statistical methods to use historic data to augment clinical trials and evaluating outcome reporting biases.
For further information, see https://www.share-ctd.eu and www.nature.com/naturecareers/job/12810214/...
------------------------------Martin PoschCenter for Medical Data ScienceMedical University of Vienna

THE MARCUS AUTISM CENTER
The Marcus Autism Center, in conjunction with the Emory University School of Medicine and Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, is offering five fellowships: the Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience, the Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience, the Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice, the Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research, and the ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science. 
Students who will receive a bachelor's degree by June 2024 will be eligible for the positions. The fellowships will commence in July 2024, and they are 2 years in duration. Students can find further details here. 
Attached, please find a brochure describing the fellowships. Please feel free to print the brochure and post it in your department. I ask that you let us know that you have received this e-mail and that you forward it, along with the associated brochure, to students in the Department of Quantitative Theory and Methods. 
The Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience will involve cutting-edge social neuroscience and/or neuroimaging research in infants, toddlers and adolescents. Fellows will work to further the understanding of autism through eye-tracking research, guiding a project from the point of data collection to publication of results. 
The Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience will involve integrating computational strategies with clinical research goals. Fellows will develop methods for the analysis of visual scanning and eye-tracking data, computational models of visual salience, and data visualization techniques, all with the aim of advancing the understanding of autism and efforts at early diagnosis. 
The Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice will involve research in educational innovations in autism. Fellows will learn about classroom-based interventions to increase social emotional engagement and inclusion, gaining experiences with observational research methods, practical experience through direct classroom responsibilities, cutting edge intervention research, and implementation science approaches. 
The Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research will select fellows for a two-year training in clinical assessment measures and research methodologies to better understand ASD and related disabilities. 
The ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science will select fellows for a two-year training in research focused on community engagement participatory methods, translating evidence-based treatments for autism into community settings, as well as the processes and partnerships that support these efforts. 
Thank you for your help! We look forward to hearing from you. 
Sincerely, Marcus Predoctoral Fellowship Committee

Spring 2024 QTM Undergraduate Teaching & Mentorship Application
 
The Spring 2024 QTM Undergraduate Teaching & Mentorship Application is now open. We are seeking TAs, Lab Assistants, and Graders for QTM 100, 110, 150, 151, 200, 210, 220, and 350. See attached for more details 
 
Submitted by Lora McDonald
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Opportunity                                                
 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
THE MARCUS AUTISM CENTER
The Marcus Autism Center, in conjunction with the Emory University School of Medicine and Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, is offering five fellowships: the Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience, the Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience, the Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice, the Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research, and the ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science. 
Students who will receive a bachelor's degree by June 2024 will be eligible for the positions. The fellowships will commence in July 2024, and they are 2 years in duration. Students can find further details here. 
Attached, please find a brochure describing the fellowships. Please feel free to print the brochure and post it in your department. I ask that you let us know that you have received this e-mail and that you forward it, along with the associated brochure, to students in the Department of Quantitative Theory and Methods. 
The Cohen Fellowship in Developmental Social Neuroscience will involve cutting-edge social neuroscience and/or neuroimaging research in infants, toddlers and adolescents. Fellows will work to further the understanding of autism through eye-tracking research, guiding a project from the point of data collection to publication of results. 
The Simons Fellowship in Computational Neuroscience will involve integrating computational strategies with clinical research goals. Fellows will develop methods for the analysis of visual scanning and eye-tracking data, computational models of visual salience, and data visualization techniques, all with the aim of advancing the understanding of autism and efforts at early diagnosis. 
The Louise and Brett Samsky Fellowship in Educational Science and Practice will involve research in educational innovations in autism. Fellows will learn about classroom-based interventions to increase social emotional engagement and inclusion, gaining experiences with observational research methods, practical experience through direct classroom responsibilities, cutting edge intervention research, and implementation science approaches. 
The Sally Provence Fellowship in Clinical Research will select fellows for a two-year training in clinical assessment measures and research methodologies to better understand ASD and related disabilities. 
The ACCESS Fellowship in Implementation Science will select fellows for a two-year training in research focused on community engagement participatory methods, translating evidence-based treatments for autism into community settings, as well as the processes and partnerships that support these efforts. 
Thank you for your help! We look forward to hearing from you. 
Sincerely, Marcus Predoctoral Fellowship Committee

content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
 
 
 
MESSAGE FROM DR. DOMINICK ROLLE,
DIRECTOR OF UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH PROGRAM IN THE PATHWAY CENTER
 
(SUMMER UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH EXPERIENCE)
 
This ten-week program offers undergraduates the opportunity to engage in a full-time research experience.  They receive a $3500 stipend and are housed for free at Clairmont Campus. 
 
Students are required to work with a Faculty Mentor, either in-person or virtually, to create a project which they will present at the SURE Symposium which concludes the program. 
 
For the first time, the URP Office will offer Faculty Mentors in the Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences generous stipends for their mentorship of undergraduate researchers during the summer in $1500, $2000, and $2500 increments. 
 
There is a significant underrepresentation of undergraduate researchers in the Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences participating in SURE. We strongly encourage you to motivate promising students to apply to participate in the next cohort of SURE Researchers in Summer 2024. The application opened on October 31, 2023 and will close on February 4, 2024.
 
For your convenience, I have attached fliers which you may disseminate to your classes and faculty to encourage participation. Should you wish for me or a member of my team to promote SURE at a faculty meeting or class, please do not hesitate to email me at drolle@emory.edu. Thank you for your time and consideration. 
 

See attached SURE flyers
                                                                                  
 Submitted by Dominick Rolle,  PhD, MBA

Hello Sociology Undergrads,
 
For Sociology Research, we offer the Sociology Research Apprenticeship (SRA), which provides semester-long research opportunities (fall and spring semesters). This is a Sociology Department program which our faculty use to find undergrad RAs. NOTE: Our faculty do not generally use the College SIRE program. If you want to do Sociology research, you should apply to SRA. 
	•	Here is the SRA program description and link to application: http://sociology.emory.edu/undergraduate/sra.html
	•	For SRA Spring 2024, Applications are due December 1. 
	•	Email your completed application form to BOTH Arlo Pittman (arlo.pittman@emory.edu) and Prof. Scott (tscott@emory.edu).
	•	Please be sure to read the information on the website!
	•	If you are accepted, then the SRA course enrollment will happen during the first week of classes (so you may want to swap out another course for SRA).
                                                                                  
Submitted by Tracy L . Scott, PhD
 
 
 
 
                                                                             

 
 
 
 
 
 The Carnegie Gaither Junior Fellowship, which provides substantive work experience at the Carnegie Endowment in Washington, DC, for students with a serious career interest in international affairs. Junior Fellows live in Washington D.C. for a year after graduation, providing research assistance to scholars working on the Carnegie Endowment programs. Students may have the opportunity to conduct research for books, co-author journal articles and policy papers, participate in meetings with high-level officials, contribute to congressional testimony, and organize briefings attended by scholars, journalists, and government officials. 
 
Students apply to a particular program/project, some of which have specific requirements. Here are the programs with requirements:
 
·        Democracy, Conflict, and Governance
·        American Statecraft
·        Nuclear Policy
·        Technology and International Affairs—Strong writing skills and research skills are essential.
 
·        Middle East—Strong reading fluency and the ability to perform academic as well as on-line research in Arabic essential. Strong background in Middle East politics and/or history is a huge plus.
 
·        International Security and Political Economy [to work with the International Security and South Asia Programs]—Quantitative data analysis and GIS skills are required. A strong mathematical background is a plus. An academic background in international relations theory or international political economy along with an interest in military issues is essential.
 
·        Asia Program—Mandarin Chinese language skills are essential. Proficiency in another Asian language is a plus.
 
·        Russia and Eurasia—Excellent Russian and/or Ukrainian reading skills required.
 
·        Africa Program
·        Global Order and Institutions
·        Sustainability, Climate and Geopolitics—Basic data skills (such as helping create graphs or tables for Carnegie publications) are a plus. Applicants should have completed coursework related to sustainability and climate issues.
 
·        Europe—Fluency and the ability to perform research in a European language other than English are a plus. Background knowledge on European politics is essential.
 
 
See flyer for more details.
 
 
Submitted by Bridget Hansen

WAE Roundtable Discussion on Teaching Local Movements
                                                   
 
See attachment
 
 
 
 
 
Course offered
 
Population Biology and Evolution of Diseases
 
See attachment
 
 
 
 
 
 
Announcement
 
BIOL485: Bioinformatics, by Y. Bromberg.  3 credits
What this course IS:
This course is designed to introduce biologists and computer scientists to basic bioinformatics concepts, principles, and techniques within the framework of command-line and web-based databases/tools.
Students that take the course are expected to:
1.     Know how to work in a command-line environment and have a basic understanding of programming/scripting. The course includes a brief introduction to writing Python scripts but requires prior understanding of programming concepts.
2.     Have a working understanding of general biology, evolution, biochemistry, and genetics concepts. The course includes only brief summaries of the necessary bio concepts and requires pre-existing knowledge.
By the end of this course, students will possess a bioinformatics skill set, including an informed vocabulary and knowledge of basic script development, sufficient for a productive collaboration within a multi-disciplined research team.
 
What this course IS NOT:
This is NOT an applied methods course; rather, this class is aimed at understanding of underlying algorithms. We will NOT attempt to list all available tools or teach you how to use them. Method selection, along with the corresponding cutoffs, thresholds, and settings, is specific to each and every research project. If you keep up with the class material you will understand the method underpinnings and be able to able to optimize your project choices on your own.
 
This intro course is also NOT intended for advanced computer science students looking to develop algorithmic expertise in bioinformatics.
 
Course Objectives
1.     Teach students to cast a biology problem as a bioinformatic problem, provide them with the skills necessary to independently select relevant tools, optimize their settings, and build pipelines to solve the set problem.
2.     Introduce students to the current bioinformatics algorithms/concepts and their implementations and prepare them for more advanced bioinformatics courses.
3.     Teach students a sufficient bioinformatics skill set, including an informed vocabulary and knowledge of basic script development, for productive collaboration within a multi-disciplined research team.

subject: An offer for Students who completed QTM  340
content:
SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT
 
FROM DR. JO GULDI
 
 
QTM 490R: Research Lab
“Using AI to Assess the Documentary History of Climate Change: A Multidisciplinary Approach”
 
As carbon and methane emissions shape our shared future, one essential question is how organizations, institutions, and markets are adopting or failing to adopt new regulations and practices for carbon mitigation and adaptation. An enormous number of published texts document the regulatory life of organizations involved with climate change, including the publications the United Nations, the quarterly reports of U.S Corporations, the World Bank Reports, the Building Codes that govern city, county, and state sustainability plans, and the bills passed by nations. 
 
To date, few scholars have attempted to deploy AI to inspect this documentary record.  As a result, we have little insight into the successes, failures, and promise of initiatives represented by this documentary base. Research in Computer Science by specialists in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and the Digital Humanities (DH), however, hold promising keys for moving from large language models to accurate depictions of historical change in the recent past.
 
Our research will apply these new methods to understanding contemporary institutions. We will connect modern white-box methods from Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Digital Humanities (DH) to the data of climate change governance, illuminating the history of official promises and regulation attempts, and allowing researchers to assemble a timeline and critical account of how climate governance has been changing over the past five, ten, and twenty years.  
 
What will the course be like? In a research lab, we don’t have a set syllabus as in a seminar or lecture series. In lab meetings, student teams plan ambitious projects of understanding, hear from invited experts, plan to seek out specialty knowledge around campus, and present their results for group review.  Readings are assigned as students require input to direct their work on a series of interrelated research problems that they work on in teams. The result is that every student participates actively in shaping their own research agenda, with guidance from the professor and other students.
 
What will I study? Current research projects include these topics:
-                      The historical analysis of text over time, showing the evolution of political promises, regulation, commodities trends, and technological adaptation across different nations and markets 
-                      Legal issues about corporate and state responsibility  
-                      Sociological and historical questions about the evolution of institutions and promises in Brazil, Tanzania and Ethiopia and other developing nations, as well as issues about the inclusion of indigenous property rights and political participation 
-                      Statistical inference about relationships between text-based promises and quantitative data on climate change, for instance, electricity bills, satellite data showing rainforest cover,  georeferenced carbon emissions, and data about human displacement and conflict, so as to determine where political and corporate promises have been realized 
 
What data will I be working with? Databases we are being assembled by students involved with Guldi Lab include these:
	•	The documentary publications of the UN regarding REDD, the governance framework for assessing rainforest governance
	•	EDGAR, quarterly reports of U.S. publicly-listed corporations discussing their investments in climate mitigation technologies as well as their interest in a shifting profile of agricultural products
	•	The MEDIACLOUD database of news stories from major cities as well as the developing world
	•	The reports of the WORLD BANK that govern major investments in the developing world
	•	MUNICODE, a database of building codes from American cities, counties, and states which govern the standard of sustainability to which new buildings must be built
	•	The CONGRESSIONAL RECORD, the annals of debate in the U.S. Congress 
 
What does it mean to take a multidisciplinary approach to climate governance? Experts currently advising the Guldi Lab include:
	•	Prof. Fouad Jabber, Professor of Agricultural Engineering, Texas A&M
	•	Dr. Mindy Goldstein, Emory School of Law and Climate Law Clinic
	•	Dr. Kevin McAlister, QTM/Political Science
	•	Mr. Marcelo Santos de Rocha Silva, Engineering Management, UC Merced, a specialist in Brazil, REDD data, and indigenous governance
	•	Dr. Emil Keme, Indigenous Studies, Emory
	•	Dr. Adriana Chira, Department of History, Emory
	•	Prof. Thomas Rogers, Department of History / Environmental Studies, Emory
	•	Dr. Rahul Bhargava, Northeastern University, College of Arts, Media and Design
	•	Dr. Katie McDonough, Digital Historian, Lancaster University
	•	Prof. Ethan Zuckerman, U Mass Amherst, Public Policy, Communication, and Information
	•	Prof. Craig Hadley, QTM, specialist in the sociology of Africa
	•	Dr. Sandeep Soni, QTM, specialist in NLP
	•	The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS), Woodruff Library
 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University
Email: shanna9@emory.edu | 470-620-7981
(she/her/hers)

	•	The CONGRESSIONAL RECORD, the annals of debate in the U.S. Congress 
 
What does it mean to take a multidisciplinary approach to climate governance? Experts currently advising the Guldi Lab include:
	•	Prof. Fouad Jabber, Professor of Agricultural Engineering, Texas A&M
	•	Dr. Mindy Goldstein, Emory School of Law and Climate Law Clinic
	•	Dr. Kevin McAlister, QTM/Political Science
	•	Mr. Marcelo Santos de Rocha Silva, Engineering Management, UC Merced, a specialist in Brazil, REDD data, and indigenous governance
	•	Dr. Emil Keme, Indigenous Studies, Emory
	•	Dr. Adriana Chira, Department of History, Emory
	•	Prof. Thomas Rogers, Department of History / Environmental Studies, Emory
	•	Dr. Rahul Bhargava, Northeastern University, College of Arts, Media and Design
	•	Dr. Katie McDonough, Digital Historian, Lancaster University
	•	Prof. Ethan Zuckerman, U Mass Amherst, Public Policy, Communication, and Information
	•	Prof. Craig Hadley, QTM, specialist in the sociology of Africa
	•	Dr. Sandeep Soni, QTM, specialist in NLP
	•	The Emory Center for Digital Scholarship (ECDS), Woodruff Library
 
 
Sadie Hannans
Undergraduate Program Coordinator
Department of Quantitative Theory & Methods
Emory University

 Announcement                                                                                 
 
 
 
You are cordially invited to the roundtable discussion “Stop Cop City”: Unpacking the Struggle Over the South River Forest. The roundtable will take place on Thursday, October 26, 6.00-7.30pm, in White Hall room 208. The event is intended to be an informative session. It brings together scholars and activists to discuss intersecting themes surrounding the debate over the South River forest: environmental justice and racism from a historical perspective as well as the recent criminalization of political protest. 
 
Four outstanding speakers will walk us through the complex issues surrounding the struggle over the South River forest here in Atlanta, Georgia: Dr. Jacqueline Echols, Board President of the South River Watershed Alliance; Sasha Tycko, PhD student in Anthropology here at Emory University; Jaanaki Radhakrishnan, Emory undergraduate and student representative for Emory's chapter of the "Stop Cop City" movement; and Selena Coppa-Caldera, Emory School of Law JD student and National Lawyers' Guild representative. The panel will be moderated by Dr. Frank Voigt, DAAD-Lecturer at the Department of German Studies.

Opportunity
 
The Center for RISC at the University of Chicago is hiring Analysts! We are an unconventional nonprofit founded by Dr. Steve Levitt (of Freakonomics fame). Our goal is to identify and scale unorthodox solutions to some of the world’s biggest social problems. Our team is advancing the smart use of technology in criminal justice, helping potential organ donors reach donation weight, and modernizing approaches to K-12 education, to name just a few.
 
You will join a small team whose backgrounds have included data science, economics, mechanical engineering, and philosophy, and who have worked in tech and venture capital, consulting, and policy. Analysts will be responsible for researching the root causes of various social issues, proposing creative solutions, and piloting those solutions.
 
Ideal candidates are curious and resilient self-starters who are excited about our mission and willing to venture off the beaten path. We welcome applicants from all fields of study! 
 
Application Deadline: Closes 11:59PM CDT October 12th
Start date: January or August 2024, full time
Location: Employees will be expected in our Hyde Park (Chicago) office 2-3 days per week
Salary: $70,000+, commensurate with experience
Work Authorization: RISC does not sponsor H-1B visas, but as a result of our affiliation with the University of Chicago, non-US citizens working at RISC can obtain J1 visas.
 
To apply to the job, click here
To see the full job description, click here
To learn more, check out our website or sign up for a virtual info session on September 20th or October 2nd

Opportunity
                                                            Message from Ariya Maskara
 
My name is Ariya Maskara and I am a Sophomore at Emory University. I am one of the Research coordinators in a student led club called Science Art Wonder (SAW). In SAW, we connect artists with researcher’s and allow the artists to take inspiration from their researcher’s scientific findings and eventually make an art piece based on it. We have an exhibition at the end of semester where we display student artwork and encourage the rest of the Emory community to be scientifically and artistically engaged in various topics. In the past, our artists have drawn inspiration from research in biology chemistry, psychology, sociology, physics, political science, and many more fields. 
 
I am writing to you with the hope of connecting with student researchers in your department who might be keen on sharing their research projects or articles with our club and be paired up with artists who can take their research forward in a creative way. 
 
 
                             Submitted by Ariya Maskara

Opportunity
Aetna/CVS Health Actuarial Presentation
Date: Tuesday, 9/19/2022, 5:30 PM EST
Location: White Hall Room 103
Target Audience: Students interested in learning more about actuarial science / students interested in pursuing the profession (generally but not limited to Math/Business/Economics/Statistics Majors)
The Actuarial profession is an exciting field for students that have strong technical & analytical skill sets. Our work is a blend of math, data science, predictive analytics, statistics, economics, & finance depending on the project... or even day of the week! At this info-session you will get the chance to meet and learn about this profession from two actuaries working at Aetna/CVS Health in the Atlanta area (however we do have offices all over the country), including one Emory alumni.
We will discuss both
internship &
full-time opportunities that you can apply for as soon as possible! Aetna/CVS Health is a great company to work for, and within the actuarial department you
 get an amazing opportunity to provide meaningful analysis, reporting, & recommendations for a company at the forefront of the healthcare sector.
The actuarial field does not require any graduate-level degrees, instead we have a series of exams that you take prior/during your career,
 with promotion and salary incentives the more exams you pass! We will be happy to discuss our experiences with the exams and give you firsthand advice on the process as well.
 
               Registration for this event is open on Handshake https://app.joinhandshake.com/emp/events/1350950
Charles Greenwald is an Emory alumni who will be visiting with a colleague to share more about internship and full-time positions  in the Actuarial Science field.
